Document Sources.Sourced Statement: This May, the Economic Roundtable, the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study, submitted its report to the L.A. Housing Department.
Document Sources.Source Justification: the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Four months later, the city still has not released it publicly.
Document Sources.Source Justification: the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.
The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year, setting up what is sure to be a fierce debate at city hall.

Over the course of 193 pages, the report offers an extensive analysis of the L.A. rental housing market, challenges facing both tenants and landlords, and the impact of the city’s Rent Stabilization Ordinance.
About 35% of the rent L.A. tenants pay goes to operating expenses for apartment buildings, on average.
From January 2020 through January 2023, 4 in 10 rent-controlled L.A. apartments became vacant.
When a tenant leaves a rent-controlled unit, the city’s rules allow landlords to raise rents to market rates.
These higher rents helped landlords absorb the impact of a nearly four-year freeze on rent hikes.
Many expenses have risen sharply for landlords in recent years, outpacing inflation.
Property insurance costs have roughly doubled since 2020.
However, the report notes these expenses make up a relatively small portion of overall costs.
About one-fifth of L.A. renters are living below the federal poverty line.
According to U.S. Census data, just over half of those renters spend 90% of their income or more on rent.
Rent increases can leave these low-income renters vulnerable to displacement and homelessness.
The city’s current range of allowable annual rent increases — anywhere from 3% to 8% depending on inflation — is higher than the increases permitted in most other California cities with rent control.
The report makes some recommendations on how the city could change its formula for determining annual rent increase limits:
Either eliminate a provision allowing landlords to raise rents an extra 1% per year if they pay for a tenant’s gas, plus another 1% if they pay for electricity — or replace it.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The report makes some recommendations on how the city could change its formula for determining annual rent increase limits

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report estimates each 1% increase could raise rents an additional $150 to $240 per month after 10 years, more than the actual cost of providing those utilities.
One option, the report says, would be to instead use a surcharge that better captures the increased costs of providing those utilities.
Change how annual rent increases are calculated.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The report makes some recommendations on how the city could change its formula for determining annual rent increase limits

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Instead of using a version of the consumer price index driven to a large degree by housing cost inflation, the report recommends a different index that excludes housing costs.
The report argues this would stop the feedback loop of allowing high housing inflation to create further housing inflation.

Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles pointed to recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners, concluding that California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Document Sources.Source Justification: recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report notes that because L.A. has a 3% floor on annual increases — even in years when the consumer price index is lower — landlords have often been allowed to raise rents above inflation.
Between 2010 and 2020, the consumer price index in L.A. rose 21%.
During the same period, rents in rent-controlled L.A. apartments were allowed to rise 36%.
On the other hand, the report finds that landlords have faced unique challenges — particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The report also notes that high turnover helped landlords raise rents to market rates and keep rental income nearly at pace with inflation.
The report recommends the city instead target aid to small landlords, rather than allowing additional rent increases on tenants.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Last October, Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez put forward a motion calling for a fresh look at the city’s decades-old formula for setting annual limits on rent hikes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Last October, Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez put forward a motion calling for a fresh look at the city’s decades-old formula for setting annual limits on rent hikes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Councilmembers Bob Blumenfield and Hugo Soto-Martinez

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles pointed to recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners, concluding that California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He said the report takes a macroeconomic view of the city’s rental market, but fails to capture the unique struggles facing many small landlords.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are plenty of owners out there who have had their renters in place for many years,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They're way below market.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: And they're having trouble today keeping up with the growing costs of insurance, maintenance and supplies.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,” said Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,” Boyar said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We are obviously in a homelessness crisis in L.A., and if this formula isn't updated soon, more folks will just fall into homelessness.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Daniel Flaming, president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report, said he didn’t have a good answer for why the report was kept under wraps.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I think when it's a politically contentious issue, there are attempts to manage the conversation,” Flaming said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The substance of the report is final.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It was submitted as a final report and accepted by the city as a final work product.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week the document was still a “draft report,” and they didn't have a specific date lined up for its release.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are several rounds of revisions left to go before this report is considered final,” Sandow said in an email.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Economic Roundtable is under contract to complete this report through January 2025 — though clearly we hope to have it finalized before then.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: By the end of last week, Sandow sent LAist a version of the report she described as "final."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: On balance, Flaming said the report shows that L.A.’s policies diverge significantly from how other California cities handle rent control.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He said the utility surcharge in particular seems “arbitrary.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The Los Angeles ceiling and floor are atypically high for rent-controlled cities,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Among cities that have elected to control rents — and not all cities have — Los Angeles appears to be tilted toward landlords.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The cost of electricity is just going to continue going up,” Yukelson with the Apartment Association said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: If the city stops landlords who provide electricity from raising rents an additional 1% per year, he said, “The next tenant is going to have to pay that burden, because the rents are going to have to go up.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Soto-Martinez, one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned — has already called for capping increases at 3%.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In an email reacting to the Economic Roundtable report, Soto-Martínez told LAist, “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: This May, the Economic Roundtable, the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study, submitted its report to the L.A. Housing Department.
Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week the document was still a “draft report,” and they didn't have a specific date lined up for its release.
By the end of last week, Sandow sent LAist a version of the report she described as "final."
LAist noted in its correspondence with housing department officials that the report was not a draft but was a finished product submitted by the contractor.
